At 5â€™9â€ and 154lbs, the â€œlabour automation unitâ€ is the coworker who never calls in sick, never complains about overtime, and somehow always looks sharp. And by â€œthe world,â€ we mean retail, manufacturing, logistics, and pretty much any industry that involves repetitive tasks humans would rather avoid.Â Â  Rather than plotting world domination, Humanoidâ€™s founder Artem Sokolov envisions a future â€œwhere humans and machines work side by side, not in competition, but in harmony.â€ â€œThis societal shift will address social issues such as workforce shortages and ageing population while giving people more freedom to focus on more creative and meaningful work,â€ says Sokolov, a serial entrepreneur and investor who founded Humanoid last year.Â  â€œThe strongest argument in favour of humanoids is that the world is already designed for humans.â€ This means humanoids â€“ unlike robot dogs or wheeled robots â€” could move about our world with ease.Â  Humanoid is still in the early stages of developing its robot, and it better hurry up. The space is getting increasingly crowded.Â Â  Teslaâ€™s Optimus is set to go on sale as early as this year, while Boston Dynamicsâ€™ Atlas continues to backflip its way into our dreams (or nightmares?), and Chinaâ€™s Unitree bots are perfecting their dance routines. html:
UK-based startup Humanoid has just shared a first look at its prototype humanoid robot â€” the HMND 01. Itâ€™s not here to overthrow humanity (yet), but it may walk, work, and possibly even out-dress you.

At 5â€™9â€ and 154lbs, the â€œlabour automation unitâ€ is the coworker who never calls in sick, never complains about overtime, and somehow always looks sharp. Yes, HMND 01 comes with a range of interchangeable outfits.Â 

The humanoid is no slouch, either. It can walk at a brisk 5.4km/h, carry up to 15kgs, and work for four hours straight before it needs a coffee break. Or should I say, electricity recharge.Â 

Check it out for yourself in the video below:

The ğŸ’œ of EU tech

The latest rumblings from the EU tech scene, a story from our wise ol' founder Boris, and some questionable AI art. It's free, every week, in your inbox. Sign up now!

Humanoid claims its bot has human-level (or better) dexterity for complex tasks and can navigate tight spaces like a pro. Whether itâ€™s lifting, packing, or navigating tight spaces in a warehouse, this robot is ready to take on the world. And by â€œthe world,â€ we mean retail, manufacturing, logistics, and pretty much any industry that involves repetitive tasks humans would rather avoid.Â Â 

Rather than plotting world domination, Humanoidâ€™s founder Artem Sokolov envisions a future â€œwhere humans and machines work side by side, not in competition, but in harmony.â€

â€œThis societal shift will address social issues such as workforce shortages and ageing population while giving people more freedom to focus on more creative and meaningful work,â€ says Sokolov, a serial entrepreneur and investor who founded Humanoid last year.Â 

â€œThe strongest argument in favour of humanoids is that the world is already designed for humans.â€ This means humanoids â€“ unlike robot dogs or wheeled robots â€” could move about our world with ease.Â 

Humanoid is still in the early stages of developing its robot, and it better hurry up. The space is getting increasingly crowded.Â Â 

Teslaâ€™s Optimus is set to go on sale as early as this year, while Boston Dynamicsâ€™ Atlas continues to backflip its way into our dreams (or nightmares?), and Chinaâ€™s Unitree bots are perfecting their dance routines. These robots are poised to take over the jobs we donâ€™t want to do â€” and maybe a few we do.

So whether youâ€™re excited or nervously side-eyeing your toaster, one thingâ€™s certain: the future is looking decidedly humanoid. Now, if youâ€™ll excuse me, Iâ€™m off to buy a new outfit. If the robots are going to out-dress me, I might as well go down in style.
